nodes.text: IT projects entail a hidden, fat-tail risk of rare but very large cost and schedule overruns (Black Swans) that can sink companies and executives, so top managers must explicitly assess and manage this risk
We conducted the largest global empirical study of IT change initiatives, examining 1,471 projects to compare planned budgets and expected benefits with actual costs and results

The sample characteristics: average project cost was $167 million, the largest project was $33 billion, sample contained mainly public agencies (92%) and US-based projects (83%), and projects covered ERP, management information, and CRM systems
Aggregate average cost overrun across projects was 27%, which conceals a fat tail of very large overruns
One in six projects was a Black Swan with an average cost overrun of 200% and an average schedule overrun of almost 70%, indicating a disproportionate number of catastrophic outliers
By focusing on average overruns, managers and consultants miss the real risk posed by the damaging outliers in the fat tail

Many catastrophic failures are documented: Levi Strauss incurred a $192.5 million charge and CIO resignation after a $5 million SAP project, Kmart experienced multi-project failures contributing to bankruptcy, Auto Windscreens and Toll Collect experienced failures leading to bankruptcy or huge public revenue loss, and Hong Kong airport IT glitches cost an estimated $600 million
Large IT projects often amplify existing company vulnerabilities (eroding margins, cost pressures, heavy debt) and can fatally compound those problems

Managers should perform a stress test: assess whether the firm can absorb a 400 percent overrun on its largest tech project with only 25 to 50 percent of projected benefits realized, and whether it can absorb 15 percent of medium projects exceeding cost estimates by 200 percent

Practical risk-reduction practices include breaking big projects into limited-size modules, setting contingency plans for unavoidable risks, resisting scope creep, and assembling stable, competent teams
Use best forecasting techniques such as reference class forecasting, which bases estimates on outcomes of similar projects in other organizations
Top managers must pay careful attention to IT projects because reliance on analytics and periodic technology overhauls makes such risks inevitable and potentially profound

A success case: Emirates NBD completed a large, merged-core-banking big-bang rollout with only 7 percent schedule slip and 18 percent cost overrun by sticking to schedule, limiting scope changes, modularizing the project, assembling the right team, preventing turnover, framing the initiative as business not technical, and focusing on readiness to go live

Engineering and product managers often lack sufficient understanding of implementing complex software components, which contributes to configuration and integration failures in product-centric projects

Configuration and version mismatches across distributed development teams (example Airbus A380 wiring and software version inconsistencies) can cause major delays, financial loss, reputational damage, and executive resignations
